description.text:
Storage Bin Laptop Stand

Author: Donald L. Merand for Explo
Source Model Link

What Is It?

This is a laptop stand that fits into a storage bin. At work, I often switch desks, and want to take my laptop, and a pile of supplies with me. We also have these storage bins sitting around, as well as some convenient wall mounts and shelving for them. So I figured, why not have a portable storage solution that uses what we've got?

I can't recommend purchasing the particular bins I have, but something like this might work. On top of the bin, this model holds 13" Macbook Pro, though it'll probably work with an Air as well. Of course, you can edit a copy of the fully parametric Onshape source model if your laptop has different dimensions.

How Do I Make One?

You'll be needing a laser cutter, and some 6mm thick material such as plywood or acrylic. You'll also need some M3 bolts + nuts. The ones I used are 19mm long. If you want to change the model to different material thickness, the Onshape model is fully parametric, so modify to your heart's content, and then just re-export as DXF + convert to whatever your laser cutter needs to operate (mine does PDFs).

Note that the PDF I've attached is for the first iteration, without cable holes underneath (see the CAD rendering for details). The DXF file I've attached has the holes.

title: Folger Tech FT-5 FT-25 Control Panel Cover for 2004 LCD w/ 60 degree viewing angle

description.text: I designed this to replace the original melamine FT-25 control panel cover. This has a 60 degree viewing angle and a small kill switch to stop the print. I have printed this, and successfully fit the stock 2004 LCD panel inside. Because tolerances are tight you may need to lightly clean out the nob and kill switch holes with a blade or deburring tool. Inserting the SD card is easy through the provided slot. To pull out the SD card put your thumb on top of the card and bring your index finger around the back of the control panel, then pinch the card between thumb and index finger and pull out card.

Printer:

Original Prusa I3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 Microns

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed this with a 20mm brim to prevent warping.

Tight Tolerances

A little cleanup in the nob and kill switch holes with a blade or deburring tool to ensure smooth operation of these parts. You will want the nob and kill switch to move freely but not be sloppy.
Autodesk Fusion 360

author: LineKernel

print_settings.Notes:: The total weight of the case and four drawers was ~135grams. The case used ~75grams of plastic, and each of the drawers used ~15grams of plastic.

description.text:
This is a small set of drawers I created as an experiment in spiral/vase printing. Each of the drawers has about 50 x 80 x 35mm of usable storage space. The drawers are suitable for light things such as electronic components, but may not be rigid enough to store nails and such. The case will fit on a 120 x 120 x 100mm printing bed.

The drawers are a loose fit in the case, so the model can be rescaled to some extent. If using different settings to mine check the fit of the first drawer before printing the rest so you can adjust the scale if required.

Printer:

Cocoon Create

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Notes:

I printed both the case and drawers using the spiral/vase printing function in my slicer. The printer has an 0.4mm extruder, but I've set the shell thickness to 0.8mm so that the printer smooshes out more plastic to draw a thicker line.

You will only be able to print one drawer at a time using spiral printing. The models have not been hollowed out so at this point they may not be suitable for other printing methods.

The total weight of the case and four drawers was ~135grams. The case used ~75grams of plastic, and each of the drawers used ~15grams of plastic.

print_settings.Notes:: I used #4 1/2 screws to attach the bottom.  No threading or nuts required.

title: Piggy Bank Safe w/ Removable Bottom

description.text:
For my son's first birthday he received a few cash gifts and we needed somewhere to put it. I wanted a piggy bank shaped like a safe with his name on it.

The safe in the picture was printed at 3/4 scale. I designed it to fit the Monoprice Mini Select bed, but after seeing it in Cura I decided to scale it down a bit.

NOTE: These files do not include "Hudson's Safe" across the top. It's just blank.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.175

Infill:

20

Notes:

I printed this with the door facing up which gave me the best detail, but required support on the entire inside of the piggy bank. I used PLA. The bottom required a little bit of sanding to fit so I opened it up .25mm in this file.

I used #4 1/2 screws to attach the bottom. No threading or nuts required.
Designed in Fusion 360 in about 30 minutes so forgive any mistakes :) I added "Hudson's Safe" by importing an .svg from illustrator with the text into the design.

This is an OpenLOCK E (2x2) floor tile that can supply battery power to any or all of it's OpenLOCK ports. Use it with the powered OpenLOCK clips to power other tiles like the torch wall.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

Supplies
  • All 3 printed parts
  • Superglue
  • Aluminum foil strip, 3 inches wide
  • Hobby knife and or wire cutters to clip the aluminum foil to length
  • CR2032 battery (see the torch wall for a recommendation of where to get one)

Important Note: At every step you can, test with an LED to make sure all the connections are still working fine. You are going to be super unhappy if you glue the top on and then it stops working because you didn't test.

Parts Take the aluminum foil and fold it along the length until you get the width of the foil down to under 5mm wide This aluminum strip will be somewhat ridgid (at least compared to the foil). Cut some lengths from this about 2 inches long. Fold the aluminum to create a contact, and fold it around part 3 in one of the divets. Glue part 3 into part 1 Put the battery in, writing side (larger side) up Fold the top contact roughly like this

Glue the top down (yes, this means that the battery is glued in, so try not to waste it. They should get ~ 20-30 hours). Prime and paint.

description.text:
This is an OpenLOCK A wall tile with an LED torch. It can be powered with the battery floor tile, and connected by a powered OpenLOCK clips.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

Supplies
  • Wall printed parts and torch printed part
  • Pin Vice (optional)
  • Aluminum foil strip, 3 inches wide
  • Hobby knife and or wire cutters to clip the aluminum foil to length
  • Hot glue gun and hot glue

I recommend getting walmart tea light votive candles. This is a case where walmart's drive to drop the price as far as they can plays really well for us. They use fewer parts then anyone else, so this means that it's literally just a few plastic pieces, a flickering yellow led and a battery. When you take it apart, you get an led that isn't soldered to anything, and it's leads aren't clipped, making the torch process easier. Read about this below the instructions.

Important Note: At every step you can, test with a battery base to make sure all the connections are still working fine. You are going to be super unhappy if you glue the back on and then it stops working because you didn't test.

Clear out the holes in the torch with the pin vice, or look at the [powered clip]() for instructions on how you can bodge a workable plastic drill with the copper wire.

Run the LED leads through the torch. Test it against a powered base, WITH THE TORCH FACING LIKE IT WILL ON THE WALL to make sure the leads are in properly. LEDs can only be wired one way, so be very careful that you are not positioning these backwards.

If you flip the battery base upside down but leave the torch right side up, that will be the correct circuit. Push the leads against the aluminum in the battery base hole to test that it lights.

Paint the torch however you want to. I use an umber brown, and a dry brush of a lighter brown, with bronze for the rings.

Finally, use the hot glue gun to put some hot glue on the LED itself. Use a toothpick (or something similar) to try and shape a flame.

Paint wall part 1 and 2 before wiring. Put a dab of hot glue on the back of the torch, then push the leads through the holes in wall part 1.

Put the aluminum up through the interior holes. Fold down the leads, and place them inside the folds of the aluminum. If you have the right skills and equipment, you can solder the leads to the foil.

Hot glue the interior to insulate the contacts and to hold everything into place. Slap the back on while the hot glue is still sticky. I use hot glue here because it's easier to open up in the future if you need to then superglue.

Walmart tea lights. These come with the proper battery you need Interior is super simple The LED's leads just run through the plastic Allowing you to separate the LED easily, ready right away for use.

author: GamingDub

title: Parametric Gear Pulley Hole Resizing (Mendel Drive Pulley)

description.text:
I developed a OpenSCAD script to fill and re-cut the motor shaft hole in an existing STL file. The specific use here is to fill the original hole in the Mendel drive pulley and re-cut it as a \"D\" shaped hole for a Lin Engineering 4218L-01-11. The script is written such that you specify the STL file you want to change, the center of the hole, and the size of the new hole, so it can easily be changed to modify ANY gear/pulley to fit ANY motor. The script also has a test mode where it can generate a cube with the new hole in it. This will print faster and let you check the fit on your motor. Attached are the following:
The new drive pulley - drive-pulley3off-_NCL_hole_Mod.stl
The OpenSCAD script - ModDrivePulley.scad
The test block - PulleyHoleModTest.stl
The original reprap STL - drive-pulley_3off.stl

• Adjust settings for your motor shaft
  • Select test mode block size (10 should be good, 1cm)
  • Print test block
  • Check fit - If good go on to 5, else go back to 1
  • Adjust settings for your STL file
  • Print your new adjusted part

description.text:
A prop guard for the Hubsan Q4 (H111)/ Estes Proto X Nano/syncro/SLT
3-21-14 v2 fits all current quads.
6-16-14 v3 The lightest you could probably design a guard for a Proto.
8-12-14 v3.34 for enhanced 34mm props
I'm a little disappointed with Estes qc and their motor pods being so loose.

v2 was designed to fit later quads and also fits older ones with the smaller motor holder. The only other difference I can find is the serial number ending in 25 instead of 15.
v3 even lighter and designed to minimize motor tweak. If you're still having issues I'd suggest gluing the pods onto the frame. The first generation of these micros had rock solid pods.

author: bluecometlover

description.text:
This is the first design I've made for 3D printing, but the concept came to me far before I got this Monoprice Select Mini I've used.
It's quite a particular case. I have a home studio with a separate booth to record and needed a way to hold the cables between the booth and the studio itself. As I didn't want to drill the walls, I passed the cables through a interior terrace from window to window. Needed something to hold the cables over the studio tables and the window sills and came up with this.

So the premise was to do something simple that I could attach to a table and a window sill without drilling, and with holes enough to hold the two cables that I have now plus two other holes just in case.

Quite basic, but does the job. It doesn't have top holes because it's designed to be set in place with a drop of hot glue, as I wanted something I could remove easily when moving. With a strong top part to deal with that (a bit rough).

This is the first working model after a bit of a struggle with hole sizes and this unbelievably thick HDMI cable :)

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

15%

You may want to scale the drawer z-height to 99% because the first one I printed was a little too big and needed a lot of sanding to get a nice fit.

title: Roomba Cliff Sensor Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A quick idea, or concept if you will, for a solution to the anxious Roombas out there. This thing is meant to cover the sensors that keep your robot from falling down the stairs or from falling from balconies. The only problem with these sensors are their tendency to confuse dark carpets or rugs with endless voids. Resulting in the carpets being left un-vacuumed.

Remix this! For flexible filaments, for better fit or for other models of robots. Make it pretty or tough as h*ll!

The thing-model is unfortunately a mess at this state, it was modeled on the fly or while falling asleep. There has been a number of prototypes made, seven to be more precise, so we know it will print. We sliced with Cura, and you might get different results with other slicers (with the model being what it is and all). But you know, please remix this.

We will continue to work on this when we find the time. We fixed our iRobot Roomba 880 for now, but there are some tweaking and cleaning up to do in the model. In the future we want a snap fit, and a smooth underside at least.

We recommend shiny, bright filaments which reflect the rays from the sensor we are trying to cover. We used white PLA and it worked very well. The model will probably need some support while printing. Sand and cut if needed.

comments.text: Thank you for posting this design. This is not printing properly. Problem slicing with Slicr and Prusa Control causing some parts of the models are unprintable. Able to slice with Cura but when having issue printing as well. I also tried high resolution but still the same.
comments.author: joreal

comments.text: Hi! Unfortunately I'm not surprised. As it says in the description, this model is a mess. But it slices OK with Cura, or at least it used to. It's marked as a work in progress but the status for this thing is there is no development right now. There will be some time in the future, when we get some extra time on our hands but until then it's posted here as a concept and inspiration. We invite everyone to remix this and make it better, and it's probably best to redo the model from scratch using only the dimensions when doing so. You can try repairing it with Netfabb or similar software if you want. I hope you try remixing it, and that you're not too disappointed in it not working! We really appreciate you telling us what you tried and what the conclusions were. I'll update the description with this new information.
comments.author: joreal

remixed_from.title: Anet A8 filiment spool holder replacement foot brackets

description.text:
I bought some kilo filament spools and wanted a wider unwind stand than the stock width that came with the ANET A8, a 130 mm strut. So here is the 160 mm strut.

The quick change spool sprocket is by jadames and you can see my make and the required hardware list here: https://www.thingiverse.com/make:442287 I made two! This with the ANET stand and the wider strut fit the Monoprice kilogram spools which are 57 mm ID, 194 mm OD, 76 mm Wide.

I did a remake using Goldie1471's foot bracket as basis for the wider strut to fit the stock ANET spool holder. It is longer and has added stress relief holes and scallops to reduce print warpage.

A two up gcode file is included in the downloads to get you going.

Printer:

Anet A8 Prusa i3 kit clone

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printer settings are speed 60, temp 200 C, plate 60 C, 1.75 PLA, and flow 100%. Build with 8 mm brim from my file above PI_Spool_Strut_160_mm_2up.gcode 80x160x4 mm and estimate 4 hr 2 and 6.7 m -- I call the part a strut, means the same as foot bracket. Thanks Goldie!

AFTER: jadames spool chuck on bearings with 5/16ths rod, the 160 mm strut at bottom BEFORE: 8mm rod through 1 kg spool with no chucks, does not turn well, note new 160 mm struts in red to space A side pieces wider for screw chucks in AFTER photo

Use TinkerCAD group and hole commands to make piece

Goldie's piece had the screw slots on the end so I didn't have to do that work of making slots. What I needed was a spool strut piece 30 mm longer than the stock strut for the 140mm screw and nut chuck of jadames for my 57mm ID spools of 1kg. I imported Golidie's piece into TinkerCAD. I moved the piece to the left 15 mm. I imported the piece again. The new import is moved right 15 mm. Since this was the first time I used TCAD I just hit the arrow keys 15 times, each tap of the arrow key is a 1mm move. Eventually I figured out how to just fill in the XYZ dimension boxes, it's quicker to move a part that way. So I selected both parts and did a union (old school) by picking the 'group' command. From there I picked a hole piece and used a cylinder of 15mm diameter and placed 5 of them uniformly through the center of the strut. Why 5? Aesthetics, it just looked nice. I printed the part and it warped badly so I placed 10mm half circle scallops on the edges, offset 3mm, to reduce the edge stress. You just make this stuff up as you go along, I thought 6 scallops of a slightly shallow half circle would work, and yes it does. The part no longer pulls up during the build but is still prone to some warping. Put the top side of the build to the outside when assembling the spool holder.
PEZ Head replacement
Pop off the old head with 2 small screwdrivers and pop on the new one.

Extruder fan cover for geeetech i3.
It snaps into place. This solves the problem of the screws being too short for using a cover.

title: Pen holder for plotting, to fit quick-fit x-carriage

description.text: This is a simple pen holder, that should work with pen-shaped items up to around 12mm diameter. I plan to use it for putting etch resist onto pcbs.

You need: 2x M5 nuts
2x M5 bolts (at least 15-20mm long, can be longer with no problem)
1x penholder.stl
2x thumbwheel.stl
2x thumbwheelcap.stl (optional, hides bolt heads, but has no functional purpose) I sharpened the end of my bolts on my lathe, but this really isn't necessary. Simply glue the bolts into the thumbwheels, put nuts inside the channel (they should be a snug fit, but you can always glue them in), optionally glue the thumbwheel caps on, then insert pen. I haven't tested this yet because my printer with the quick fit carriage isn't fully built, but it holds a pen very firmly.

description.text: Our laser cutter's compressor came with a 1/4 inch snubber as an inlet filter which once clogged with dirt would starve the compressor. After cleaning the snubber a few times I elected to buy a replacement and went for the cheapest I could find on amazon. When they sent me a 1/2 inch snubber despite clearly advertising 1/4 inch I thought to myself this is a much better solution, it'll take far longer to block! Only problem was fitting the two together on a reasonable budget. Without buying multiple adapters to take the 1/2 inch male NPT fitting down to 1/4 inch female NPT on the compressor nor spending loads for a metal fitting (it doesn't even need to be water/airtight) I elected to 3d model and print my own.

comments.text:
Hi Stoehrmannmj
I'm assuming the distorted form isn't intentional?! -anyway I also enjoy scanning interesting shapes and objects and from my own experience i'm guessing the shiny reflective surface of the Lego man is to blame for the distorted model, I had this same issue problem with some of my early scan attempts and i overcame the problem by giving my object a coat of matt emulsion stippled on to refract any light and give a nice easy texture to scan.
I would suggest not using a colour too dark or too light, so probably don't use white or black instead ideally use grey but again not too dark.
To improve the result further maybe giving the object a stippled coat of a light grey or even magnolia and then once dry do a second stippled patchy coat of a darker colour so to give the object a patchy speckled two tone matt finish which will offer the photogrammetry scan software plenty of markings and points of reference between the frames.
ONLY USE EMULSION (water soluble paint) as this will wash away relatively easily with warm/hot water and soap
DO NOT USE GLOSS as this will have a shiney finish difficult to scan and almost impossible to remove, potentionlly damaging the item.
Do not use this method to scan items of significant/high value or items which may retain/absorb the paint such as wood or other rough textured/ porous surfaces.

title: PiGRRL Zero Plus with Backlight Control

description.text:
This is a PiGRRL Zero with brightness control.

  • This is a purely software remix of the PiGRRL Zero Plus. Please ignore any model files attached to this project.
  • This remix has NO SOUND

Here is a demo of how it looks:

The four brightness settings I went with were:
Full: 1023/1023
Half: 500/1023
20 percent: 200/1023
5 percent: 50/1023
They seem to closely resemble DS Lite brightness settings, which I was generally happy with.

I wrote a gist for the python script that controls brightness: https://gist.github.com/lindsaylandry/f30cc0740bc20461edf79f7c452dcc39

Place this file in /usr/local/bin/backlight.py

Next, I created a systemd service that will call this script upon system startup. Write the following code to /etc/systemd/system/backlight.service
https://gist.github.com/lindsaylandry/b975615a43f82f80e433a400808d2daa

Finally, enable this service.
sudo systemctl enable backlight.service

This service doesn't properly start unless the GPIO pins have been properly reassigned. The GPIO responsible for backlight control on a PiTFT, #18, is by default mapped to the left key. I had to reassign the left key to GPIO 4, both by soldering and adjusting some software.

The following instructions are for reassigning GPIO pins if you haven't done so already.
To reassign pins, rewrite the following line of /home/pi/Adafruit-Retrogame/retrogame.c
{ 18, KEY_LEFT }, // Left becomes { 4, KEY_LEFT }, // Left

also comment out any reference to GPIO 27 if it exists.
//{ 27, KEY_4 }, // TFT 27

Recompile with the following command:
make retrogame

Replace the current retrogame executable (stop retrogame process before doing this)
sudo cp /usr/local/bin/retrogame /usr/local/bin/retrogame-bak #first backup original executable
sudo cp /home/pi/Adafruit-Retrogame/retrogame /usr/local/bin/retrogame

Finally, restart the pigrrl. Backlight service should be up and running!

IMPORTANT NOTE: The original build has GPIO 18 used as a sound amplifier because it is a PWM. I couldn't figure out to have both sound and backlight control, so this build functions with no sound. Sorry folks! D:
If someone could figure out how to have sound work too that would be awesome.

Hit me back if you have any questions about this, and happy hacking!

comments.text: This is pretty awesome! Last time I checked there wasn't any open GPIO pins left after you attach audio and all the buttons, however I've thought about putting the two gamepads and bumpers together as a USB controller, which should free up majority of the GPIO pins.

Simple two-chambered pill box. The box is compact and features a sliding lid that reveals only one of the pockets at a time for easy use.

title: Dice that won't roll off the table

description.text:
To throw the dice, a double action is required. Firs rotate the dice as fast as you can with one sweep of your fingers. Stop them by pushing the stop button.
The outside of the dice has a dark color. A light colored insert makes the dots visible.
The shaft is a 120mm M5 threaded rod. it is attached to the bracket with two nuts. At both sides a dice slides over the shaft and is secured with a self locking nut. Make sure the dice rotate freely. The shaft for the stop button is M3. Good practice: Drill all the holes to their intended dimension.
https://youtu.be/QFgmIKAay1g

With three rotating elements it should not be too difficult to build a one armed bandit.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2131803

title: Thinner case for Behringer VD-400 delay pedal

description.text:
I wanted a delay effect, but one that takes as little space as possible in my Ukulele bag. You'd think some kind of minimal plug-in effects existed, but I didn't find much, so I compromised by buying a cheap delay, the VD-400 from Behringer, and making a smaller housing for it. I had to remove the pedal to make the box smaller, but for my purposes, that's fine. It's still nowhere near as small as I'd like, but the PCB was pretty big to begin with. 
I think next I'll look into some kind of more software-oriented solution for effects... Maybe a Beagleboard or something could be  used to run basic audio processing. Pedals seem to be made the way they are simply because they need to be pedals, there has to be a way to make an effect processor smaller.

The part should fit fairly well in this, although it's pretty tight. The LED hole needed to be enlarged just a bit after printing on mine. The battery goes between the PCB and the front of the case. The wires need to be pushed around a bit to get the case to close. I used the knobs from the original unit. I moved the toggle button to the front of the unit since I got rid of the pedal, the niche at the bottom is for the button. Glue it on there after soldering wires on? The whole thing is held together by 3 M3 bolts. 3 because putting a fourth one in at the remaining corner would have meant making the box larger... I figure it's good enough.
The design includes small "mouse ears" at the corners as I got some pretty bad warping due to the size of the object. They seem to help, though the result is still not perfectly flat.
I ended up printing my box on card since I didn't have any tape wide enough to cover my Makerbots build surface and having a seam in the build surface really messed things up. The prints do stick to the card pretty thoroughly, but soaking the print in water afterwards for a short while lets you rub off the paper pretty easily, and what's left after that can be sanded off without much trouble.
The SCAD file is pretty messy. Sorry about that! It's the first thing I've done with OpenSCAD, and I'm pretty lazy about cleaning things up...  For the text on the front, I used stuartpb's Spiff Sans, which is referenced by the SCAD file, so you'll need to download that if you want to do something with the SCAD.

Wounded Cupid (1873 or 1875), Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux (1827-1875), marble, Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek (Copenhagen, Denmark). Made with Memento Beta (now ReMake) from Autodesk.
This work by J.B. Carpeaux (1825-1875) named “L’Amour blessé” was inspired by his eldest son (Charles Jean Louis), a 3-year-old who had injured his arm.
The original (0.497 cm 0.363 cm 0.182 cm), in bronze and whose wings have disappeared, was melted in 1873 by “Susse Frères”. It is preserved in the Musée d’Orsay in Paris.
In 1874, a marble of 0.80 m in height was acquired by Prince Stirbey who then gave it in 1921 to the Museum of Fine Arts of Valenciennes (France). Two copies of this work, made in 1875, were given for one at the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek in Copenhagen and at the Museum of Fine Arts in Nancy (France)
Many other copies, of varying sizes, in bronze, terracotta and plaster have been made and have been distributed worldwide. Thanks Pattarian for the informations
For more updates, please follow @GeoffreyMarchal on Twitter.

author: tracknet

description.text:
Python script to generate a random 2D maze of any size using Eller's Algorithm. The output is an OpenSCAD array definition with blanks and walls represented as 0 and 1 respectively. For more information on Eller's Algorithm see here:
http://weblog.jamisbuck.org/2010/12/29/maze-generation-eller-s-algorithm

I intend to eventually use this for randomly generating a maze bolt/box with smooth inner walls. The number of horizontal and vertical cells are specified on the command line: ./eller_generator.py 15 5 > maze_new.scad Generating the maze definition should be very quick, but compiling in OpenSCAD may take a while depending on the size of the maze. Using the minkowski sum, you can generate rounded edges (see the 'punch' STL/SCAD file). Comping this takes ages (about 5 mins for the example file due to intersecting edges), but displaying is fairly quick. Update 2013-Dec-26.1: fixed an X/Y bug in the OpenSCAD code for drawing the maze
Update 2013-Dec-26.2: fixed floating point division bug in punch down probability calculation
Update 2013-Dec-26.3: adjusted maze extrude height to maze height
Update 2013-Dec-27: Fixed set union bug that was causing loops to form

description.text:
This is my first extension for the analog stick on the PS4. I've made many for the PS3, some successful, some not. I even machined an aluminum version with interchangeable tops!

-Update V1.1-
Reduced size of clips on bottom for easier removal.
Added a chamfer on bottom edge for better clearance.
Didn't need support printing on makerbot replicater+ for some reason, though I would recommend still using supports.

This works much better than my old PS3 versions as the top of the PS4 stick is much more flat, and therefore easier to model for since you don't have to try and perfectly match a curve.

This is super grippy and I love my homemade versions better than any store bought ones. They also print in only 15 minutes!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

10%

Notes:

You need the support for the concave where the stick actually fits. I haven't tried printing upside down, but the details are so fine and support material would be too hard to remove.

I've printed with 5 shells, effectively solid since it is so small.

A set of two Mortal Kombat Keyrings. A Klasssic and MK9 style logos.

I would recommend a 3D Print Direct printing services for their cheap and incredibly strong carbon fiber reinforced SLS nylon material:

http://3dprintdirect.co.uk/
@3Dprintdirectuk

title: Robot Vision: Optical Tracking Ball for Pixy Sensor 75mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:795052

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=795052

The Techroom Robotics Club has a contest to find and retrieve a ball. We tried bright orange whiffle golf balls but at only 40mm in diameter the vision system could not distinguish the golf ball from a half meter away. Experimentation showed that 75mm diameter offered a good vision range compromise. The Customizable cat toy ball generator by tkbletsc offered a perfect solution for the 75mm whiffle ball and it can be made in almost any color. This contest is based on the concept of retrieving Alan Shepard's lunar golf ball from February 6, 1971.

author: Speed3903

description.text: This is a mount and duct for a 40mm cooling fan that will fit the std Sells Mendel X carriage. I could only find one fan mount for this venerable machine and I wanted to duct air closer to the hot end than this would allow. The duct will mount 40mm fan and attaches to the carriage by replacing one of the belt clamps. I have sized the model for my Mendel on which I have replaced one of the belt clamps with a tensioning clamp. Which you can find here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16012. The model is slightly optomised from the one I printed to save on plastic and weight. Please be sure to that when your print is finished your skeining software homes to Y =0 and X = 130, i.e. over the purge plate at the last layer height. If you home X = 0 to high up the Z axis then a crash may occur due due to the reducing size of the triangle frame work. This is one of the reasons I am moving to an Orca so that the X axis is fixed at the top and I can hang all sorts of crap of it the SCAD file started out with the intent of being parametric but a failed big style so mega hacking is required if you want to use another size fan.

• Print 1 fan duct, one belt tensioner set
  • Drill through the base on the fan mount ( the holes will act as guides )
  • Mount the fan and check you are getting enough air flow
  • Remove the standard X axis belt straps
  • Replace the 40mm cap screws on the left strap with some 65mm lengths of 4mm all thread

  • Assemble as shown in the photos, I used an aluminium shim between the duct mount and the belt clamp

  • When you Print turn the most detailed side of the model towards the duct outlet

author: camillanordin

title: Fatshark 18650 Case with Charge indicator support
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I created this Fatshark 18650 Battery case so you can get up to 6 hours of battery time with your Fatsharks. This holds (2) 18650 batteries and uses all the wiring and components from an original fatshark battery pack including the battery charge status led indicator.

Take apart your original fatshark battery and move the parts into this case. You will need 2 18650 batterys available on ebay.

Several youtube videos online to show how to make the connections including soldering.

Enjoy!

comments.text: When printing there is a 13.50mm space between the top of the battery and the cap. And the case will not fit in the goggles. The overall height is 86.402mm. It is to big. I am using cura and a MP Select mini printer. I am not sure if its no scaling correctly or if its is meant to be this way? And if I scale it down I am worried the indicator will not fit correctly. Thoughts?
comments.author: Gs550t1981

comments.text: The one seen in the photo is the only one I printed, both batteries as well as battery indicator fit. there is room above and below batteries to allow for wire routing if needed. The case with batteries fit into the fatshark elastic loop.. because the whole case is larger the fit is tighter.
comments.author: Gs550t1981

comments.text: Ok so maybe I just need to try stretching it some more. I'll try when I get home. Thanks.

description.text:
"Frabjous" is a scupture originally created by Georg Hart. It's made of 30 identical S-shaped pieces. Original by George W. Hart
georgehart.com/sculpture/frabjous.html
Remade by Evil Mad Scientist Laboratories
evilmadscientist.com/article.php/frabjous

Print about 30 at a scale of your choice and assemble.
Use this laser-cut model to help you http://blog.gagalabs.com/laser-cut-frabjous Took users @ifalicov advice and have now added the file for a single arm, Enjoy! -Please note that Frabjous(1) sets up about 10 prints on a replicator platform to save you time! =D

comments.author: richgain

description.text: behold an M3 Bolt

title: Fully Parametric Matchbox
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Written in OpenScad, this is a fully parametric match box. It consists of an open drawer and a sleeve.
I designed with parametrization in mind. You can adjust width, length, height, drawer hole radius, wall and bottom thickness, tolerance between parts, and added a full customizable parameter for the sleeve, where you cand a custom text or graphic (via .dxf file).
Text and graphic parameter can be turned on and off. Text size can be adjusted, and .dxf file path too.
Added 4 basic .dxf graphics for you to try: smile.dxf, clip.dxf, domo.dxf and heart.dxf.
Added 3 basic printables: plain matchbox, "hello" matchbox and smile matchbox.

UPDATE 02/28/2017: I corrected some errors in the code, like the sleeve's width parameter, now has a better tolerance. I re-upload the .scad and the .stl files.

UPDATE 03/10/2017: Fixed a sleeve's width tolerance issue and made the drawer puller hole bigger. Also made text and graphics not totally hollow, in order to make sleeve easier to print. I re-upload all the files.

comments.text: Looks like the box versus the sleeve need to be tightened up a bit.  There is no friction between the two, so it falls right out.  Easy enough to fix myself, just wanted to let you know.
comments.author: chrisgo

comments.text: I'll look into it, chrisgo. Thanks for comment.
comments.author: chrisgo

comments.text: Thanks for this model!   The original cap on my tube of epoxy had the top half split off while it was sitting in storage, so I appreciate the "over-engineering" in this design.  :-)     Only change I had to make was scale by 0.9 to fit a tube of J-B Weld epoxy.

print_settings.Notes:: I remember printing my original sliding block at either 102 or 103% and then sanding the sides to fit. the reason was so the belt would fit in easier. depending on your setting you may need to drill out the mounting holes. The sliding block is printed with the countersunk hole on top, this way no supports are needed there. They are needed for the arch, and there is a built in support for the bearing mount.

title: BL Touch-X belt tensioner WanHao I3 v2.1

description.text:
I made this to combine the BL Touch auto level sensor and the X-belt tensioner that I'm using so I would have a one piece unit. My printer is down as of this writing so I haven't been able to test it.

UPDATE 3/1/17: I printed one out after getting my printer closer to normal. I found a couple of areas that needed help. I fixed one and made a place to put supports better for the of the BL Touch holder/bearing cover and smoothed a few edges. There is now also one for those that upgrade to the E3D V6 hot end as well. enjoy and give feed back on what could make this better.

UPDATE 3/4/17: I caught an error in the file, it has been corrected. IF YOU DOWNLOADED THIS BEFORE DELETE THOSE FILE AND GET THIS ONE. The tensioner block will not fit the bearing block properly in the old version.

The sliding block is printed with the countersunk hole on top, this way no supports are needed there. They are needed for the arch, and there is a built in support for the bearing mount.

print_settings.Notes:: they will thread together directly off the printer and the M8 nut will thread onto any M8 threads with no post processing. the M8 bolt is slightly oversized to ensure threading with the 3d printed nut.

description.text:
This is a 3d printable M8 bolt and nut. it is a fun print to test your printer with as it requires good print cooling.

they will thread together directly off the printer and the M8 nut will thread onto any M8 threads with no post processing. the M8 bolt is slightly oversized to ensure threading with the 3d printed nut but if you use a M8 nut to post process the threading using some vice grips and forcing it the threads can be made to M8 metric standards.
